content.description:
An inclined slab, not using the crack to the left.

In between the two cracks on the face.
7 bolts with rappel rings and anchor on the top.

This is the left of two cracks in the face.  Quite pleasant, takes a variety of gear, but mostly in the 1" and up range.

Varies in width. SR to #3 BD should do it. You can put a #4 but it's not strictly necessary.

climbs.name: Dance Eat Sleep Repeat
climbs.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olson, and friends 2015-2017

content.description:
Follow the obvious hand crack up to a few slab moves to finish at the bolts.

The right hand of two parallel cracks on the main face of Free and Easy wall.  This one has a small chock stone ~5ft below the horizontal crack.

Two bolt anchor at top.  Gear to 3"

Thin gear in the seam protects a stout runout.



Follow the thin crack above/left of the first bolt on Range Ball Wrecker then move slightly right following crimps and a horizontal.

SR to 2.5, RPs

Ascend the finger crack up in under the roof.  Reach out to jam the crack at the end of the roof and pull through to the upper section of the route.

Leftmost crack still under the large overhang on Free and Clear
Fingers to hands; bolted anchor at top

climbs.name: Insta-Graham
climbs.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olson, and friends 2015-2017

content.description:
Ascend the corner crack just to the right of the large roof (not under the roof).  At the horizontal crack mid way up the ledge begin to work left to the upper left crack.

Bolted anchors at top.

This route starts on the rounded arete between Range Ball Wreckers and the Free n Easy roof.

A difficult boulder problem uses a thin vertical crack feature to gain a bulge with a deep horizontal crack (optional cam placement). The route continues up the slab with two more bolts and a good jug between them.


Bolts, single cam

need info, to be entered in the future

bolts

The corner to the right of Trippy Squirrel.

Gear

Cruxy down low, cruisy in the middle, then a bit cruxy again up high. It climbs similar to Appmaster (the 10b slab to the left).



To the right of Trippy Squirrel, in the left face of the dihedral on the lefthand side of the crag.

8 bolts

Start up some fun juggy moves protected by a bolt into a rambling low angle (essentially walking) corner until you get to the 5 meter finger crack in the steep headwall (crux). 

Be aware that a fall off the headwall wouldn't be great as you'd be hitting the low angle ramp below. 



The obvious low angle corner groove next to Shimmering Crack.

Standard rack and 1 bolt down low. Crux takes small gear.

climbs.name: Pocket Change
climbs.fa: Alan Stevenson, Erica Olsen, and friends 2015-2017

content.description:
Start up the fine hand crack past the horizontal ledge.  Clip the one bolt on the face which protects the 10b face move up and to the anchors.

One of the two main cracks on the Free and Easy wall; left of 'Dance Eat Sleep'
Hand crack size; one bolt; bolted anchor at top

Climb up a short, cracked slab to crank through the obvious roof cracks on mostly bomber jams.
Using the ledge to the far right puts the grade at 10+.

The obvious roof at Free and Easy, just right of the crag's namesake route. You can't miss it.
BD-sized cams .5-3 should do it. Protects great, just don't get your cams sucked into the crack!

Fun climb with only a couple hard moves

Could be done on bolts, option of adding two cams.  One low down and one right before the bolt

Left leaning crack that thins out to tips, moves right to a tricky mantle move on bolts


Gear to 0.75, 2 bolts

A tricky highstep from an easy slab leads into a finger crack in a corner that quickly steepens.
Pull around the lip and romp to the anchor, clipping a bolt on the way.

Hanging LFC to the left of the obvious crack pair of Cragger/Trippy Squirrel.
Thin gear protects the crux moves. Hand-sized and a bolt after the corner.

Feeling like all the cool new climbing adventures are way out of your league?

Want to turn a normal day cragging into a silly outing? Say no more!

May we present to you The Smoke Bluffs Interconnector! A 12 pitch multi that ties together some classic crags and lesser known pitches from the Blind Channel all the way to Nighthawk Lookout!

All crag and route info can be found in the new guide book, and there are more than a few variations at most crags to turn this novice route into something a bit more spicy.

Climbing isn't always about huge objectives and crushing hard sends. Sometimes its just about being silly and having fun! 

So get out there, mix it up, and have fun, fellow weirdos!

Much Love, Erica Harvey and Ryan Thomas Pierce



Route starts at the Free and Easy Crag. Summit is accessible via various mountain bike trails in the upper section on the bluffs. Descend via Upper Loop Trail.

Standard double rack to BD #4. Variations could effect this.

The first bolt line to the right of Dance, Eat, Sleep, Repeat. Tricky friction slabbing continues up past the horizontal break and up a ramp to the anchor.


boltz

The wide but low-angle crack splitting the face to the right of Cragger.

SR to 4"

Very slabby climb that starts with a few nubs that will hold decently. Initial bolt is kind of high, 3rd bolt is kind of reachy from the right, Harder route (11b/c) is to go at the slab head on. Easy route (11a) is to avoid the slab and go right. Climb a thin finger crack on the right of the bolts as you get sucked into the offwidth cave between the rocks that allows decent fist jams at the crux. Climb up to the 4th bold for a bouldery move to a bowl-shaped sloppy area where the 5th reachy bolt is at. Continue climbing up right for small edges and bouldery moves to the anchor. In front of some shrubs between two rocks.

Look for two "nubs" on the bottom that stick out of the slab as decent foot holds, and another nub sticking out above in arm's reach. 5 bolts with the bolted anchor with rappel rings

After pulling through the initial steep part and clipping a bolt, the corner rocks back. A few low fifth class moves bring you to two options. Option 1: (harder), take the crack on the face on the right-hand side of the corner. Be careful not to disturb the tree frogs that reside there. Option 2: continue up in the corner, and then step right to find the anchor.

This is the dihedral right of "unknown a" in MP. 
SR to #3 BD, 1 bolt.

A bit more shaded than the cliffs above so great for hot and sunny days.

The area's left side is in development, but with bolted sport routes (from 10b to 12b), top rope anchors, and trad routes (from 5.8 to 12a) available.
